basics.name: Valentin Kapitany
basics.label: Researcher, Computer Vision
basics.summary: I specialise in both traditional and machine learning enabled computer vision for smart microscopy as a Research Associate at the University of Glasgow. In parallel, I've enhanced edge devices with AI, notably for concealed weapon detection in smart home security and 3D human motion tracking. In five years of data science, I've refined skills across the spectrum – from developing and deploying data pipelines and ML models, to storytelling through compelling visual narratives. I excel at extracting vital insights from haystacks of data, aiming to mould a more efficient, sustainable, and healthier future.

work.name: University of Glasgow
highlights: Created a data-driven algorithm that improves image resolution by up to 98%, per the LPIPS metric, using noise reduction, image registration and deep-learning based super-resolution in Python.

Improved concealed weapon detection error rate by 400% using 1300 times less memory, by optimising an AI-enabled edge-device consisting of 3D cameras (LiDAR) and radars powered by a Raspberry Pi, running TensorFlow Lite in C.

work.name: University of Glasgow
work.summary: Demonstrated courses for 3rd year physics laboratories
highlights: Laser Modes, Fraunhofer Diffraction, Polarisation, Spectroscopy
Group projects for low-temperature thermal stabilisation
Achieved world-first AI-based 3D imaging with the low-power 'SOLI' radar, through developing radar readout, optimising data storage and processing, and training then testing 3D scene estimation.
Tutored students in undergraduate-level Statistics and A-level Physics.

work.summary: Developing a Raspberry Pi-based servo-mirror controller
highlights: Created a 50-80% cheaper alternative to galvo-mirrors for laser welding.
Built and programmed a point-and-click servo-mirror setup run by a Raspberry Pi.

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
